pros: Understanding what are Corporation functions well still being at university and a society, so a very unique experience
cons: Being on the sales team you need to constantly keep motivated when you are rejected by companies

review_title: Great opportunity for a lot of effort
pros: • Great growth prospects and a chance to lead your own team with managerial responsibilities early in one's professional journey • Open and dynamic company culture with accessible leadership • A lot of flexibility with choice of position and department
cons: • For what's essentially a volunteer role, the effort and time commitment it requires can be downright excessive • Your experience will change materially depending on which branch you're part of, as well as that specific regional leadership

review_title: Great culture if you can fit in
job_title: Business Development Manager in London, England
pros: - Fun environment - Young people empowerment - Conferences are great
cons: - Micromanagement can occur depending on the team - Short terms means there is sometimes not enough time to implement changes needed/even to finish onboarding/education cycle

review_title: Great Place to Develop Leadership Skills
job_title: Local Commitee Vice President in London, England
pros: - Meet other like-minded students - Gain leadership skills through practical experience
cons: - Not any cons for being a VP

job_title: Local Committee President in Nottingham, England
pros: Meeting new people, develop your leadership
cons: Might require high time commitment

pros: great way to expose me to various challenges and methods of managing a group of students.
cons: time consuming as a uni student

review_title: Good place to develop skills and make friends
job_title: Team Member of Outgoing Global Exchange in London, England
pros: Perfect place for students to develop their public-speaking & leadership skills.
cons: In order to develop leadership skills, it requires member to apply for higher positions,

pros: Great place to learn leadership and management skills in a globally multi-cultural environment.
cons: Sometimes it can be its own bubble.

job_title: Vice President Finance in Birmingham, England
pros: The networking opportunities with people all over the world
cons: the short term limits the company in plannig for the furture

pros: Such a fantastic place to work. Made friends for life.
cons: The pay is not great. No company HR benefits.

job_title: Former Vice President in London, England
pros:
If at university as a team member, it is the greatest experience you can have. Teaches you real tangible skills such as time management, real sense of ownership and leadership.
Ability to progress through to various leadership positions
You get out what you put in. 
Great sociable atmosphere, the loveliest people in the world
Super fun and engaging. work hard play harder
cons:
- You sacrifice a lot of time for a voluntary position
Badly organised at times with power going to some people's heads
Can be very cliquey and lack of transparency at times

job_title: OGX Team Leader in London, England
pros:
Leadership: The opportunity to take charge is there for you to grasp if you want it and are willing to work for it.
Peers: Incredibly positive environment with a quirky culture and friendly pretty much everyone you'll see. 
Travel: you get a great excuse to travel and meet people from diverse geographical locations and backgrounds you would otherwise have no opportunity of knowing.
cons: It's easy to get lost in the crowd if you do not stand up, wave your arms about and shout (figuratively). No one will force you to work, if you do not have the discipline and drive to keep working for AIESEC it is quite easy to slowly disappear and be forgotten.

job_title: National Vice-President of Marketing in Sheffield, England
pros:
You will get given huge opportunities and responsibilities, causing you to learn and grow like no other.
Strong globally connected family culture
Great place to work if you want to make a difference to the world
cons:
Culture of poor work/life balance
Poor leaders can sometimes cause unnecessary stress
Poor training, most things you have to research and learn yourself.

pros:
- Focus on personal development.
- A good opportunity to get involved as a student at a university.
- Develops a good skill-set including and not limited to networking, time-management, planning, teamwork etc.
cons:
- Very few benefits received.
- Compulsory conferences which you have to pay for yourself with only a part of travel expenses subsidised. 
- Inflexible work schedules.
- All work is free of pay. 
- Exclusive culture which creates a gap between customers and the firm.

pros: It is the best way to contribute to a more diverse and open minded youth on the planet, I recommend it for every people who are at university
cons: There are no cons I could recall, it definitely take a lot of your freetime next to your university studies but worth  it

review_title: Best place to work during university studies
job_title: Local Committee President in Durham, England
pros: Strong global network. Skills development in pretty much every area - marketing, PR, sales, human resources, finance and external relations. Transferable skills gained such as leadership, team management, communication and public speaking to name a few.
cons: Volunteer work. Time management between studying and volunteering.

job_title: Vice President Marketing & Communications in Sheffield, England
pros:
- Meeting like-minded individuals full of passion and determination
- Positive, supportive working environment
- Opportunities to attend international conferences, meeting people from around the world
cons:
- Hungover mornings in conferences
- Be ready to commit if you want to be part of it

review_title: Working as a team member at university
job_title: Marketing and Communications Team Leader in Birmingham, England
pros: Friendly, inspiring and energetic environment, a place to improve a number of interpersonal skills, network with a lot of like minded young people
cons: May take a lot of time for managing, organising events, paperwork etc.

job_title: Local Branch Manager in Bristol, England
pros:
- Great culture working alongside young leaders
- I was given responsibility and ownership which helped me grow
cons: - Lots of work on weekends, which made managing work/life balance harder.

pros:
Young People
Sense of purpose and social work
International Networking
cons:
Long Hours
One Year Contracts 
Must be a member to move forward to paid roles

pros: good communication skills developed, team work is the key and made a lot of great friends
cons: not a well organized organization

pros:
-Very good experience
-You make many good contacts.
cons: -Requires many hours of work, for a voluntary position it can be very demanding and requires sacrifices.
